i should preface this with the fact that i do have some bias, as i find sci-fi to be a much more boring setting than their other series in a fantasy or post-apocalyptic world. that said, i still have lots of issues with this game which go far beyond my lack of interest in the setting.

the gunplay in this game is a major improvement over any previous bethesda games. it still doesn't feel as good as other modern first-person-shooters, but i don't think it needs to. i really feel like it's gotten to a point where the gunplay is as good as it needs to be for what is really an open-world-rpg first, first-person-shooter second. a small gripe i have however, is that the gun designs themselves are a bit uninteresting. in their pursuit of a nasa-punk visual theme, a lot of the guns don't actually make sense in how they would function. which i think is fine! however while the fallout series has plenty of guns which wouldn't make functional sense in the real world, their designs can be really unique and interesting. i found the guns in starfield to be unfortunately really forgettable - i think the corporate dystopia theme of the game played into this in a negative way, i would have liked to have more weapons i could get attached to. there wasn't any "starting 10mm pistol" to get fond of, nor was there much in the way of single-appearance unique weapons like the junk jet or deliverer from fo4. all uniques were just name and stat changes (sometimes with a paintjob swap) of an existing, normal weapon type. actually unique uniques do take more work but i feel like they're really important in giving the player something to get attached to over the course of gameplay. also, the really fun weapon (and armour) upgrade system from fallout 4 is back, but i feel like it's implemented far worse in this game. there is not nearly as much visual change with the upgrades in starfield, and overall it just feels like a much more shallow, uninteresting system which is easy to ignore for your entire playthrough. considering the potential shown by the already good system in fo4, i'm really disappointed that the modularity of weapons and armour took a major backstep rather than introducing further depth. 

a quick touch on character progression perks is that the system feels a little more rpg-ish and encourages specialisation at the start which is nice, but i really feel like far too many perks are simple number boosts, there is not nearly enough unique abilities in the perk trees to feel gratifying enough to specialise into. number-based stat improvements are boring and don't feel rewarding. specialisation as a whole also falls of a cliff, as this game strongly urges the player to spend lots of time on one single character, which means you'll become a jack of all trades at some point anyway. it makes the upgrade system feel rather meaningless.

touching on clothes and armour, the modular multi-part armour system from previous games is gone, but i feel like it hasn't sufficiently been compensated for. the armour system in this game is so disappointingly inexpressive. you always have to be wearing a spacesuit in this game (unless you're in oxygenated settlements) which is fine, that makes sense. my problem is that the spacesuits are so incredibly samey and boring. they all take up one single equipment slot for the body, along with a helmet for the single head slot, and that's it. what's worse is that the spacesuit upgrades (using the fo4 upgrade system) don't make any visual change to your suit whatsoever, meaning that the only way to get a new look is to find a different type of spacesuit alltogether - of which there are only a limited number of types. the limited amount of equipment slots, and further limited alterations to that equipment means the total number of combinations for your look is really small, and that's just really disappointing as someone who values customising their character a lot. it's a shame when they introduced a genuinely really impressive new character creator.

one major gripe i have there however is the small number of hairstyles, with no long-hair options. this feels like more of a cop-out to fit in spacesuit helmets than anything actually reasonable, more hairstyles are needed not just to make your character feel unique, but for npc variation too. the character creator in every other way is a major upgrade though, and the reintroduction of traits and the background system is super cool, i only wish it affected your playthrough more strongly to encourage specialising and trying multiple different characters out. 

the most important parts of these games for me are the quest design, characters, and open world though, and unfortunately, these three aspects are where the game flounders the most. i'll try keep it brief to not hit the character limit, but essentially: 

i found the quest design to be an improvement in some ways (the basis of most quests was really interesting), and the game makes an effort to have the player express themselves conversationally in the quests. however these points of expression feel shallow, as one recurrant theme in the quests of this game is the lack of outcome diversity. you constantly feel railroaded into one or at most two outcomes, which cheapens the effect of you expressing anything different in conversation. the most divergent outcomes come from the ending of faction questlines - however even these divergences lack npc responsiveness and integration into the world, which makes it feel like your choice didn't really matter.

characters have improved in some ways and fallen flat in others. the follower system in starfield is fantastic, the followers each feel far more fleshed out and grounded in the world, their reactivity is really important, and i think this is one of the best thing starfield does, and needs to carry into future bethesda games. the problems here are that there are only 4 unique followers in this game which have this fantastic depth, and they're all rather samey since they're from the same main story faction. i feel no reason to use the more generic followers when they don't feel like real characters who react to what i do the same way the main four followers do. i just want more of this good system, that's all. 

outside of the four major followers, i did unfortunately find a vast majority of characters in this game to be bland and forgettable, even compared to other bethesda games. the innoffensiveness of the four main followers can even include them in this conversation, despite them having the most depth in the game. i unfortunately just did not find there to be any jarl balgruufs or ulfric stormcloaks or nick valentines or mr houses in this game. i wasn't particularly excited to see anyone or learn more about anyone, it's a major point of disconnect between me and this game's setting, there aren't many people in the game's world that i actually care about. 

finally, the open world. or worlds. this is the worst part, unfortunately. bethesda's strengths are in their interconnected open world design. and this game just doesn't have that interconnectedness. they still kill it at the atmosphere and visual design of the environments, but the world (or galaxy in this case) struggles to find meaning when everything you do, and everywhere you go, is so separated from everything else. the world is cohesive and makes sense, i just struggle to find meaning or enjoyment when it doesn't feel like there's anywhere to call home - not even my ship. having a thousand different worlds doesn't make the game feel bigger, it just makes every world feel smaller, and that lack of the human touch in an interconnected world design squanders bethesda's biggest strength. 

i do think this game gets far too much undeserved hate, i think it's a good game, but not a great one. 6.9/10.

I read the reviews, I held off buying for about a year, waited for a big sale… and honestly? Starfield is exactly what you’d expect from “Bethesda in space.”

It’s Fallout. It’s Skyrim. In space. There are differences, but nothing game-changing. The gameplay loop is very familiar: wander, loot, shoot, talk, repeat. Exploring is fun at first, hopping from planet to planet and poking into random points of interest. Outpost building becomes pretty entertaining in the late game, especially if you like tinkering and planning little resource networks.

NG+ is actually one of the more interesting parts. No spoilers, but it feels less like a full reset and more like a weird, semi-continuous run that gives the game a bit of extra life if you’re already invested.

On the downside, the Shattered Space DLC was… pretty meh. The whole game feels like Bethesda *could* have gone back, cleaned things up, and really sharpened the experience based on feedback, but instead they seem to have shrugged and leaned on the modding community to fix and expand the game for them. Pretty typical at this point.

If you’re looking for a deep, memorable RPG story with rich choices and consequences, this isn’t it. If you want to build cool spaceships, shoot pirates, and play a sort of space looter-shooter sandbox, you’ll probably get your money’s worth. Especially if you grab it on sale.

Starfield – A Massive Space Sandbox, But Not Every Toy Shines the Same

I went into Starfield with a big mix of excitement and caution. After spending years in Elder Scrolls and Fallout worlds, the idea of Bethesda finally creating a brand new universe felt huge. But a part of me kept wondering if a game this enormous could really live up to its own ambition.

After many long hours, here is the truth. Starfield is huge, packed, beautiful and sometimes genuinely magical. But it is also uneven. Some moments feel like you are exploring the endless frontier of space. Other moments feel like you are staring at menus in a sci fi simulator.

The World and Atmosphere: A NASA Punk Dream, But a Safe One

The Settled Systems look amazing. The space suits, the ships, the cities, the planets and all the handcrafted zones show just how much effort the art team put in.

New Atlantis is clean and futuristic.
Neon is a neon soaked cyber city full of corruption.
Akila City feels like a frontier settlement pulled straight out of a space western.

Everything has personality.

The problem is that the universe is not always surprising. For a sci fi game with billions of possibilities, Starfield rarely feels truly strange or mysterious. It looks great, but it plays safe.

Story and Quests: Big Ideas, Good Execution

The main story about Constellation chasing mysterious artifacts has strong themes. Multiverse concepts, cosmic mystery and philosophical questions are all here.

But the actual storytelling is solid rather than unforgettable. It works, but it does not always hit with the emotional power it could have had.

The faction quests are much better.
The United Colonies feel militaristic and righteous.
Freestar Rangers give you a space western sheriff fantasy.
Crimson Fleet lets you live a full pirate life.
Ryujin Industries is all about corporate espionage.

These questlines consistently deliver better drama and more memorable moments than the main plot.

Exploration: Thousands of Planets, But Same Feeling

This is where Starfield stumbles.

On paper you can land anywhere. In practice most planets feel similar. The same structures, the same enemies, the same loop of scanning and looting. It starts exciting but settles into routine quicker than expected.

The handcrafted locations are the real stars. Whenever the game takes you somewhere designed with intention, everything improves instantly.

Space Travel: More Menu Than Adventure

Flying your ship sounds amazing in theory, but most of the time you are jumping through menus and fast travel screens. The game looks like a space exploration RPG, but the spaceship gameplay rarely reaches its full potential.

Walking inside your ship is great. Building it is even better. Actually traveling in it is limited.

Combat, Weapons and Skills: Solid but Not Revolutionary

Combat in Starfield feels good. Weapons have impact, zero gravity firefights are fun and enemy reactions are decent.

The skill system is fine but not extremely deep. Some skills feel essential, some feel pointless, and build diversity is limited compared to other RPGs.

It gets the job done but does not redefine anything.

Ship Building and Systems: The Brightest Part of the Game

This is where Starfield shines brightest.

Building ships is addictive.
Adding new modules.
Tweaking engines.
Rearranging the interior.
Creating something ridiculous but beautiful.

It is easily one of the best ship creation systems in any game.

Outposts are more divisive. If you enjoyed base building in Fallout, you will find something fun here. If not, you can ignore them completely and miss nothing important.

Technical Presentation: Beautiful but Interrupted

Starfield is visually impressive. Lighting, interiors, cities and planetary landscapes all look fantastic. Character models are much better than previous Bethesda games.

But the loading screens break immersion. There are many. Enter a ship, enter a room, land on a planet, leave a planet. These small interruptions add up over time.

Verdict: A Huge Universe, But Still a Foundation for Something Greater

Starfield feels like the first chapter of a much bigger vision. The framework is huge, detailed and full of potential, but not all systems shine equally.

It is a game you can lose yourself in.
It is a universe worth exploring.
But it is not the perfect space RPG people dreamed of.

Even with all its flaws, Starfield delivers a memorable journey. It is good, sometimes great, but not legendary. At least not yet.

8.5 out of 10 – A vast and impressive space adventure with massive potential for the future.

Starfield Feedback: A Promising Game That Needs Steady Ongoing Development

After spending more time in Starfield, I’ve seen both its strengths and areas that need refinement. The foundation is solid, the scope is impressive, and the game has plenty of potential — but like many large RPGs, it continues to evolve.

Companions & Exploration

Companions add personality, though AI can be clunky at times. Exploration is exciting, but some planets feel sparse. The concept is strong, and future updates could expand environmental storytelling.

Modding & DLC

Modding is active even without full plugin support, and the community is eager for deeper tools. I added Shattered Space later on, and while it integrates well, I think the game would benefit from more frequent updates and clearer communication.

Stability

I initially thought CTDs in the UC Education Center were part of the base game, but the real cause was a corrupted texture mod (The Eyes of Beauty). Once removed, the game ran smoothly. To be clear: the vanilla game is stable, and Bethesda wasn’t at fault.

Final Thoughts

Starfield is already enjoyable and continues to grow. With steady updates, community involvement, and expanded modding support, it can become the game many of us imagined. In its vanilla state, it works well, and Bethesda deserves credit for that. I’ll gladly update this review again with more praise if development keeps moving forward.

At current time of writing I am 91 hours through my first playthrough. I will update as I complete the game cycle over time.

So, do I recommend this game? Absolutely. Why, when it has received so much negative feedback? Simple. The negative feedback has some merit - but conditionally. There ARE lots of loading screens, yes, but they didn't bother me AND I didn't go into the game expecting No Man's Sky or Elite: Dangerous. There IS a lot of procedurally generated content and radiant quests, yes, but (a) this adds to the wonder of the game, as Gopher notes, and (b) you don't have to engage with it all (and likely can't)! This stuff didn't bother me either. I just focused on the quests, engaged with this stuff some times, and went on having fun.

Some of the negative feedback Bethesda has already addressed - like the map and some of the loading screens being made into believable content, like the Grav Jump wormhole. But SOME still remains. For instance, without spoilers, it is hard, nigh-on impossible, to be an evil character with your companions. Also, the world IS very sterile, in that it isn't too daring, dark/gritty, or able to really flesh out a 'bad' character. This is somewhat a drag, but did it reduce the fun? Not at all. Will it stop me playing lots of characters again? Not at all.

Again, yes there is a lot of nothing out there. But I never expected there to be lots - it is space. And this doesn't detract from my sense of wonder I feel. Is that for everyone? No, not at all. But for me it is still fun to explore. Could it be better to have more content? Yes. But that's what mods and Creations are for. Ok, so the vehicles could do with better handling and the space combat is janky, but I still enjoy both and mods help them be more fun.

Does that mean this game is only fun with mods? No. It just means that mods/Creations can extend its life, just like with other BGS games. I have played for 91 hours and I haven't touched the main story much yet. That's what I want from a BGS game, and I DO love Starfield.

So, is the game bad? No, not by any means. Is it perfect? Also no. Is it for everyone? Not at all. But if you enjoy BGS games and want to experience them in space, I think this game is fun and delivers a lot of fun for the price. I certainly will play this game over and over. I can see I will play this playthrough for way more than 100 hours, maybe 500+ (again, no spoilers). And I already have other characters to play and have seen others have events - in their first playthrough - that I haven't had yet. So I WANT to explore and play more.

Should you get it? That is a personal decision. Some have liked it, some haven't. But for me, I recommend this game and have already gotten my money out of it without completing this playthrough. In a word: artless. Starfield feels like the natural endpoint of a studio that has been recycling the same approach for twenty years. Everything about it looks ambitious on paper, but the game itself feels like the result of blending scale, procedural generation, and AAA risk-aversion into something strangely empty.

I’ve wanted a proper space game for as long as I’ve been playing games. I love science fiction. I love the fantasy of exploring strange worlds, finding weird little corners of the galaxy, and getting lost in something that feels genuinely unknown. But I think I finally have to accept that this kind of game might never happen at the AAA level. Starfield made that clear.

Because the moment you load into your first planet, you feel the same problem that No Man’s Sky had at launch. When you rely on procedural generation to fill the gaps between handcrafted content, you end up with a lot of space and not a lot of meaning. A hundred empty planets don’t equal one memorable one. And when you try to balance both breadth and bespoke design, the seams show everywhere.

The sad part is that none of this is surprising. Not for Bethesda. Not for AAA.

Bethesda jank used to be charming because the games had personality. The bugs stood on top of something that felt alive. Starfield has the bugs, but the personality is gone. The worlds feel assembled rather than created. The systems feel like they exist because they were on a production roadmap. Ship building. Outposts. Crafting. Factions. A thousand tasks that all blend together into the same gray paste.

This is what happens when a massive team tries to satisfy every possible audience. Too many cooks. Too much money at stake. Too many shareholders who want a game that looks ambitious without taking any actual creative risks. 

The only perplexing thing about Starfield is why they made it at all. Maybe it was the classic trap. The scope was too big. The tech wasn’t ready. The premise demanded bespoke content on a cosmic scale, which is nearly impossible to execute in a way that feels meaningful. When you try to simulate an entire galaxy, you end up with something that feels like a diorama of one.

I wanted to like Starfield. I waited years. The problem isn't unique to Starfield, it's AAA in general. You either get a giant open world packed with shallow systems, or you get a highly scripted roller coaster that barely feels like a game. There’s very little in between.

The silver lining is that indie games are better than ever. Maybe that’s where the real experiments will keep happening. Maybe that’s where someone will finally make a space game worth getting lost in.

It just isn’t this one.

Rather than feeling like an open galaxy, the world of Starfield feels more like a series of rooms with a starry backdrop.

Similarly, outpost building is an utter waste of time. There is no need to ever build an outpost - no colonies to build up and populate with settlers, no resource incentive (since you would have to build a dozen outposts to get the right combination of useful resources), and the story never touches on the feature even a little.

Apart from the problems with the space content, the actual RPG elements are all over the place. There are far too many features locked behind perks, far too many levels for each perk, and the loot system took all the worst parts of Fallout 4's insistence on being able to pick up everything while simultaneously removing any utility in doing so.

The companions in this game are mostly dreadfully dull people. I liked Sam well enough, but they are all still just a single personality trait personified. They have no nuance in thought, no real differences of opinion, barely any backstory of note. They exist merely to fill crew positions and repeat the same 3 lines of dialogue whenever you switch loading screens. You would think a guild of explorers would be full of bright-eyed, scientific, and curious minds - but you quickly realize that these people will offer nothing of value in the actual act of exploration.

Speaking of exploration... There is almost none to be had. You can land on planets, scan minerals, flora, and fauna; yes. However, there is nothing else to it other than the same randomly-generated pirate outposts, abandoned labs, military facilities, or mining outfits. There are no hand-placed nooks with secrets to find, no environmental storytelling, no surprises. It's all just an algorithm spitting out random junk and passed off as "exploration". The only incentive to even explore at all is selling the survey data - you don't get anything other than money for having done so. Of all my issues, this is the most egregious and the one that really spits in the face of any fan that was once excited for this game.
